statement.title: Extreme Value Theorem
Extreme Value Theorem
statement.paragraphs: interval $[a, b]$, then it attains both a maximum value and a minimum value on $[a, b].$

statement.title: Rolle's Theorem
Rolle's Theorem
statement.paragraphs: Let $f : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ be a function which is continuous on $[a, b]$ and differentiable on $(a, b)$ (i.e. $f'(x)$ exists for all $x \in (a, b)$). If $f(a) = f(b)$, then there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that $f'(c) = 0$.

newcol.paragraphs: that $f$ has an absolute maximum or minimum at a point $c$ in $(a, b)$. It may then be shown that: \[ f'(c) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(c + h) - f(c)}{h} = 0, \] using that fact that if $f(c)$ is an absolute extremum, then $\displaystyle \frac{f(c + h) - f(c)}{h}$ is both $\leq 0$ and $\geq 0$.

statement.title: Mean Value Theorem MVT
Mean Value Theorem (MVT)
statement.paragraphs: If a function $f : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ is continuous on $[a, b]$ and differentiable on $(a, b)$, then there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that: \[ f'(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a} \]

a.title: By 4C (Own work, based on PNG version) [GFDL (http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/fdl.html), CC-BY-SA-3.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/) or CC BY-SA 2.5-2.0-1.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5-2.0-1.0)], via Wikimedia Commons

newcol.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a function which satisfies the conditions of the theorem. Define a function $g : [a, b] \longrightarrow\mathbb{R}$ as follows: \[ g(x) = f(x) - \left[\left(\frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}\right)(x - a) + f(a)\right], \quad x \in [a, b]. \] (Intuitively, $g$ is obtained from $f$ by subtracting from $f$ the line segment joining $(a, f(a))$ and $(b, f(b))$.) Observe that: \[ g(a) = g(b) = 0, \] so the function $g$ satisfies the conditions of Rolle's Theorem. Hence, there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that: \[ 0 = g'(c) = f'(c) - \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}\,, \] which implies that $f'(c) = \dfrac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$.

section.title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

title.paragraphs: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

slide.section_title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

title.paragraphs: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

statement.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a differentiable function on an open interval $(a, b)$. If $f'(x) = 0$ for all $x \in (a, b)$, then $f$ is constant on $(a, b)$.

newcol.paragraphs: For any $x_1, x_2 \in (a, b)$, show that the difference $f(x_2) - f(x_1)$ is equal to $0$.

slide.section_title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

statement.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a differentiable function on an open interval $(a, b)$. If $f'(x) > 0$ (resp. $f'(x) < 0$) for all $x \in (a, b)$, then $f$ is
If $f$ is moreover continuous on $[a, b]$, then $f$ is increasing (resp. decreasing) on $[a, b]$ if $f'$ is positive (resp. negative) on $(a, b)$.

newcol.paragraphs: Suppose $f'(x) > 0 $ for all $x \in (a, b)$. Given any $x_1, x_2 \in (a, b)$, such that $x_1 < x_2$, by the MVT there exists $c \in (x_1, x_2)$ such that \[ f'(c) = \frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1}\;. \]

collapse.paragraphs: By the condition $f'(x) > 0$ for all $x \in (a, b)$, we have $f'(c) > 0$. Also, $x_2 - x_1 > 0$. Hence: \[ f(x_2) - f(x_1) = f'(c) \cdot (x_2 - x_1) > 0. \] This shows that $f$ is increasing on $(a, b)$.

slide.section_title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

statement.paragraphs: Find the intervals where the function $f(x) = x^3 + 6x^2 - 15x + 7$ is increasing/decreasing.

collapse.paragraphs: First, we find: \[ f'(x) = 3x^2 + 12 x - 15 \] Observe that $f'$ is defined and continuous everywhere. Hence, the intervals where $f'$ is positive/negative are separated by points $c$ where $f'(c) = 0$. (Such points are called
of $f$).
Setting: \[ f'(c) = 3c^2 + 12c - 15 = 3(c^2 + 4c - 5) = 3(c + 5)(c - 1) = 0, \] we see that the points where $f'$
changes sign are: \[ c = -5, 1 \]
Consider now the
It now follows from
and the continuity of $f$ that:

li.paragraphs: $f$ is increasing on the intervals $(-\infty, -5]$ and $[1, \infty)$.

slide.section_title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

statement.paragraphs: Let: \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} (x + 1)^2, & x < 0; \\ x + 1, & x \geq 0. \end{cases} \] Find the intervals where the function $f$ is increasing/decreasing.

newcol.paragraphs: We carry out the same steps as in the previous example. We leave it as an exercise to show that: \[ f'(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 2, & x < 0; \\ \text{undefined}, & x = 0;\\ 1, & x > 0. \end{cases} \]

collapse.paragraphs: Note that $f'$ is not defined everywhere. In this case, the points where $f'$ possibly changes sign are points $c$ where: \[ f'(c) = 0\quad \textit{or} \quad f'(c) \text{ is undefined.} \] Such points are called the
of $f$. (Note that the set of stationary points is a subset of critical points).
Constructing a sign chart as in the previous example, we have:
Hence, by
, $f$ is
on: \[(-\infty, -1],\] and increasing on both $[-1, 0]$ and $[0, \infty)$.
Since $f$ is continuous at $x = 0$, we conclude that $f$ is

slide.section_title: Applications of the Mean Value Theorem

statement.paragraphs: Use the mean value theorem to prove that for $x>0$, \[ \frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x) < x. \] Hence, deduce that for $x>0$, \[ \frac{1}{1+x} < \ln\left(1+\frac{1}{x}\right) < \frac{1}{x}\;. \]

newcol.paragraphs: We first show that: \[ \ln\left(1+x\right) < x\;. \] Consider the function: \[ f(x) = \ln\left(1+x\right) - x\;. \] Then, $f(0) = 0$, and $f'(x) = \dfrac{-x}{1 + x}$.

collapse.paragraphs: Hence, $f'(x) < 0$ for all $x > 0$.

For any $x > 0$, by the Mean Value Theorem we have: \[ \frac{f(x) - f(0)}{x - 0} = f'(c) \] for some $c \in (0, x)$. Since $c > 0$, we have $f'(c) < 0$, which implies that: \[ \frac{f(x) - f(0)}{x - 0} < 0. \]
Since $x > 0$, we conclude that $\ln(1 + x) - x = f(x) = f(x) - f(0) < 0$. We conclude that: \[ \ln(1 + x) < x, \] for all $x > 0$.
To show that $\frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x)$, we proceed similarly.
Consider: \[ g(x) = \ln(1 + x) - \frac{x}{1 + x}. \]
Then, $g(0) = 0$, and: \[ \begin{split} g'(x) &= \frac{1}{1 + x} - \frac{(1 + x)1 - x(1)}{(1 + x)^2}\\ &= \frac{x}{(1 + x)^2}\\ & > 0 \end{split} \] for all $x > 0$.
Hence, for all $x > 0$, by the Mean Value Theorem we have: \[ \frac{g(x) - g(0)}{x - 0} = g'(c) > 0, \] where $c$ is some element which lies in $(0, x)$.
This shows that $\ln(1 + x) - \frac{x}{1 + x} = g(x) > 0$. Hence, \[ \ln(1 + x) > \frac{x}{1 + x} \] for $x > 0$.

Finally, for all $t> 0$, we have $\frac{1}{t} > 0$. Applying the inequality: \[ \frac{x}{1+x} < \ln(1+x) < x \] to $x = \frac{1}{t}$, we have: \[ \frac{1/t}{1+1/t} < \ln\left( 1+\frac{1}{t}\right) < \frac{1}{t}, \]
which is equivalent to: \[ \frac{1}{t + 1} < \ln\left( 1+\frac{1}{t}\right) < \frac{1}{t}. \]
